DataElement.preferredName: Hodgkin's Lymphoma Transplantation Time Partial Remission Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the type of partial response of the hodgkin's lymphoma at the time of transplant.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Hodgkin's Lymphoma Transplantation Time Partial Remission
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A lymphoma, previously known as Hodgkin's disease, characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.  There are two distinct subtypes: nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma and classical Hodgkin lymphoma.  Hodgkin lymphoma has a bimodal age distribution, and involves primarily lymph nodes.  Current therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma has resulted in an excellent outcome and cure for the majority of patients._The grafting of tissues from one individual to another or place to place within a single individual._The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._A decrease in the size of a tumor, or in the extent of cancer in the body, in response to treatment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A lymphoma, previously known as Hodgkin's disease, characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.  There are two distinct subtypes: nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma and classical Hodgkin's lymphoma.  Hodgkin's lymphoma has a bimodal age distribution, and involves primarily lymph nodes.  Current therapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma has resulted in an excellent outcome and cure for the majority of patients. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A lymphoma characterized by the presence of relatively few malignant cells called Reed-Sternberg cells and mononuclear Hodgkin cells that are admixed with nonneoplastic inflammatory cells. The malignant cells have a distinctive immunophenotype; they are positive for CD30 and CD15 and negative for CD3, CD20, and CD45.

Concepts.definition: Transference of a tissue or organ within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.
The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.
A finding indicating that there is a decrease in the size and the extent of tissue involvement by a malignant tumor in a patient.
